<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 363, 88]]<|/det|>
Which statement is not valid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 621, 117]]<|/det|>
Current is the speed of the charged particles that carry it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 920, 160]]<|/det|>
Electromotive force (e.m.f.) is the energy converted to electrical energy from other forms, per unit charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 168, 131, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 168, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
The potential difference (p.d.) between two points is the work done in moving unit charge from one point to the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 133, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 861, 225]]<|/det|>
The resistance between two points is the p.d. between the two points, per unit current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 253, 107, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 559, 271]]<|/det|>
Which statement about electrical resistivity is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 281, 133, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 281, 920, 329]]<|/det|>
The resistivity of a material is numerically equal to the resistance in ohms of a cube of that material, the cube being of side length one metre and the resistance being measured between opposite faces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 337, 133, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 337, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
The resistivity of a material is numerically equal to the resistance in ohms of a one metre length of wire of that material, the area of cross-section of the wire being one square millimetre and the resistance being measured between the ends of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 133, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 393, 920, 424]]<|/det|>
The resistivity of a material is proportional to the cross-sectional area of the sample of the material used in the measurement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 133, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 920, 466]]<|/det|>
The resistivity of a material is proportional to the length of the sample of the material used in the measurement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A cell of e.m.f. \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected in series with a switch S and an external resistor of resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 109, 635, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 261, 376, 280]]<|/det|>
The p.d. between P and Q is \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 291, 268, 310]]<|/det|>
When S is closed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 320, 134, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 320, 532, 339]]<|/det|>
V decreases because there is a p.d. across \(R.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 345, 133, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 345, 527, 364]]<|/det|>
V decreases because there is a p.d. across \(r.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 131, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 371, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
V remains the same because the decrease of p.d. across \(r\) is balanced by the increase of p.d. across \(R.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 412, 134, 430]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 412, 833, 431]]<|/det|>
V remains the same because the sum of the p.d.s across \(r\) and \(R\) is still equal to \(E.\)

<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 700, 90]]<|/det|>
Which of the equations that link some of the following terms is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 101, 615, 120]]<|/det|>
potential difference (p.d.) \(V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 128, 615, 145]]<|/det|>
current \(I\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 154, 615, 171]]<|/det|>
resistance \(R\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 181, 615, 198]]<|/det|>
charge \(Q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 207, 615, 225]]<|/det|>
energy \(E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 233, 615, 250]]<|/det|>
power \(P\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 259, 608, 275]]<|/det|>
time \(t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 295, 138, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 288, 233, 323]]<|/det|>
\[P = \frac{Q^2R}{t}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 133, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 333, 240, 352]]<|/det|>
\[E R^{2} = V^{2}t\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 133, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 364, 213, 395]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{V I}{P} = t\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 406, 134, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 406, 225, 425]]<|/det|>
\[PQ = EI\]
